text:
Thank you for the introduction. Thank you for inviting
me to the seminar

and for the warm welcome. There are lovely conversations
I've had this morning already

and the plan for
the rest of the day.

Thank you for the
intro, mostly for, maybe, making sure everybody is
ready for something different.

[LAUGHS] I love talking to broad
audiences about my work

and about the value of
design research and research through design. And so I'm more than
happy to answer questions,

if you're like, what
are we talking about? What is going on? I love more of an
interactive, ask question

as we go type of talk. And so if you're feeling like
you don't know what's going on, just let me know.

Maybe, to help you
understand why I do what I do

and how I got
here, I'll give you just a little bit of a
trajectory for how I got there.

So I was born in Montreal. I'm French-Canadian. And so if some of the
words are a little funny,

that's because of that. And I studied industrial design
as my undergraduate degree.

So I was thinking about how
do we make physical things for people.

And then I worked
for a little bit as an industrial
designer in Montreal. But then I had so many
questions about what

happens when some of
these physical things have computation get in them.

2008 is when the
iPhone came out. And so there was, all
of a sudden, this idea that you could have
a computer on you

at all times for
anything and everything. And just really opened
up my imagination.

And I was like, OK. We need to ask questions
about what that means for us. So I moved to Vancouver, BC.

So from the east coast over
to the west coast to start a master's in
interaction design.

So moving from
industrial design, which is very much concerned
about the physical, to more questions about
the digital side of things.

And that's where I learned what
design research was, which is, basically, you can use
design to ask questions,

which is what I was doing. This is why I got there. And then also learned that you
can actually do a PhD in that.

And so I decided to
stay and do a PhD and graduated at the School of
Interactive Arts and Technology.

And then really
loved the west coast and didn't quite
want to go back home. And so I applied to an
assistant professor job

at University of
Washington in Seattle and moved down there, where
the cherry blossoms are not

quite there yet this season. This is an old photo. We are very much in
the rain right now. And so everybody's been
apologizing to me about the rain
here. And I'm like, yeah. Don't mention it. It's OK. And so there.

I started in the School of
Art, Art History, and Design. And I do have a
courtesy appointment in HCDE, which is human-centered
design and engineering,

very much core to the
HCI community on campus, as well as in the
DXARTS department, which

is the digital and experimental
art and media department.

So I really have
this position, where I can use art and design as a
way to interrogate technology.

And so a lot of what I'm
going to present today is in that space.

Who's heard of research
through design? OK. That's good.

Research through design
is a methodology, where, basically, you use
design as a mode of inquiry.

This is your main approach. So design, many
of you might know, you're trying to
understand different needs,

different contexts, and then
you're making an intervention. You're ideating. You're thinking about what could
we make to change the situation.

And then through the making,
you're discovering things. You're learning. Usually, then like that thing
goes on and exists in the world.

In design research,
we're using that thing to figure out new
ideas, new knowledge.

So at Studio Tilt, so it's
a design research studio, it's hosted at the School of
Art, Art History, and Design.

And as a studio, we question and
reimagine familiar encounters

between humans and things. It's a pretty broad statement. But this is-- if I'm trying to
explain what is it that we do,

it's really this
both the questioning. So it's critical. It's really about wondering why
are things the way they are.

And then it's also
trying to think well, if we're not satisfied with what
they are, what else could they be?

Our intention is not to design
the next consumer product. So a lot of people are
like, OK, so then that's going to be sold at
Best Buy next year.

And I'm like, no. The goal is really to
reflect, to critique,

and to imagine alternatives. And then in small, sure,
eventually, your hope is that we are leading to
better, more fair, more

appropriate, more relevant,
better for people, better for the planet products. But the step before that is
to be in that critical space.

Title of the talk
today, data imaginaries. And so, of course, in the
context of Studio Tilt,

we're in here
trying to reimagine. And so we're not trying
to reimagine data. Although, maybe a little bit.

We're really trying
to reimagine how is it that we encounter data. Everybody, when's the last
time you encountered data

that you saw or met or
felt or were with data?

Weather app this morning. OK. Yes. Saw data on an
app, looked at it,

decided it was going to rain. Any other ones? When's the last
time you saw data?

Yeah. I use my body
scale this morning.

Dedicated device, looked at the
weight, then you're like, yes.
[LAUGHS] You should.

So there's different ways we
see data in our everyday lives. Still, if I ask you,
what does data look like?

Maybe, that's what
you're thinking of. If you look in
Google, you type data, Google search image,
why is it that we always
think data in this similar way? We have all these interactions.

And yet, the way that
movies are showing it to us, any time there's a
news article about data,

there's like this weird
graphic at the top. And that's what we see. And so that frustrates me.

As a designer, I'm like,
what else could it be? Why does it have to be that? And what are the dangers
of just having that?

The real danger is that we
have a homogeneous view of what data are and by extension
of what they can do.

And so if we're able to
broaden what data are, what they look like,
or what they feel like, maybe, we can start to think
about other ways of using

or being with data that
are potentially less connected to some of the
things that, maybe, we
don't want so much. Capitalism, perhaps. Surveillance, perhaps.

Privacy questions,
questions of agency. And so these are
the kinds of things that I'm trying to shake up
a little bit with the work

that I'm doing. In the same vein, if I
ask you what is data,

these are some of the
words that you might think are connected to data. It's usually digital.

It doesn't have a
real material sense. It may feel objective and true.

It may seem homogeneous. And it can also feel
universal and clean.

You can see that there's a
white space next to that. That's because I want to
get to this other list.

What's the alternative? And so before that,
I think what's important to remember is that
the system in which data are

created-- so D'Ignazio and Klein wrote
this really beautiful book, Data Feminism-- I really do recommend
it to all of you--

where they say this
extractive system creates-- which is like the system
of capturing and collecting

and creating data-- creates
a profound asymmetry, an imbalance between who
is collecting, storing,

analyzing data, and whose
data are actually collected stored and analyzed.

The power is really, really
strong on the one side, the people who are actually
able to analyze the data.

And yet-- or the
companies, very often-- and then the people who
actually produce all that data.

And so when we're trying to
shift that to bring back power to people who are creating
data, well, maybe, we

can get to another list. What if we considered data as
local as opposed to everywhere?

What if it's lively? It has its own life. What if it becomes
a heterogeneous? It has all these
different forms.

What if, as opposed to
being a standalone thing, it really becomes
part of an assemblage,

it becomes part of the people
that created it of the local-- like the context
that created it?

What if we look at it from
a personal perspective, from an interpretive-- or interpretative point
of view, as opposed for it

to be completely objective? We know that there is human
actions throughout the process

of gathering data. Well, that's
interpretation throughout. So let's actually be
honest about it, maybe,

and agree that that's there. And maybe instead of
big data, let's think about small data for a minute.

I know these are not 1 to 1. And they are not meant to be. I'm just thinking about
two lists of adjectives
to think about data.

That's my pitch. By focusing on the more
human qualities of data, if we think about
small data, small data

calls for reducing the gap
between those creating the data and how it may be understood.

Thinking back at that
quote from Data Feminism. And so small data,
just to be clear,

doesn't mean complete
opposite of big data. Instead, small data
are intricately

linked to the large ecosystems
of big data, data economy and surveillance, but
where attention is focused

on the personal relationships. So by doing that,
I'm not saying we're ignoring all the other
links that data have.

I'm just saying,
what would happen, if we focused on those personal
links just for a minute, or maybe for the
rest of the hour?

So that's the
question I'm asking. How might creative
data representation support other
engagements with data?

We're looking at
those alternatives. We're trying to reimagine.

You looked at the data app. You looked at the weight scale. Sometimes, it might
look like this. This is a really long
spreadsheet of things.

Sometimes it's
quick visualization. Sometimes it's a dashboard,
another dashboard,

another dashboard. These are all from
smart home devices.

A lot of my work is in the
context of home, context of IoT, internet of things devices. And so you might also even
have your fridge that's--

this was a really funny thread
by Dan Hono, who said WTF. Our fridge just emailed us
to say we opened the door too

many times this past month. If this is your engagement
with data, granted this is pretty funny, but
it's funny because it's weird.
I also like weird. But is this what we want? Is this where we're going?

I hope not.  I have about four
or five projects

I want to talk about
today that are all trying to cast data in
a really different way,

really trying to go
against this, basically. Just trying to see what's going
to happen if we don't do that.

Instead, do something else.  I'll go through them
relatively quickly,

because I want to be able to
show you a variety of projects. But I also invite
questions along the way.

So the first one is
the listening cups. I'll pass them around. These are 3D printed ceramics.

They are cups. So you can wash them or
you can drink from them.

And the bumps on them
are representing sound. And so the question
we were asking was--

or the goal really
was, how do we reveal, ignore our hidden
data in everyday domestic IoT

artifacts through
physicalization? So for those of you
who might not know, physicalization is the
idea of transforming data

into a physical representation
of that data, material. So it's in contrast, perhaps,
with visualizations, which

use a 2D space to look at data. And so now, we're
engaging other senses,

because we're using
a 3D object that also has the weight and
the texture, and all that.

The data started
in a spreadsheet. Basically, this was
a very short project.

It was a one-week residency
with Timea Tihanyi who owns Slip Rabbit Studio, which
is a ceramic studio in Seattle,

where she does both
slip casting, which is one mode of
fabricating with ceramics, but also has a 3D
printer and was

really interested in starting to
play with data and the printer. And so we captured
eight short clips

of different everyday
environments. And so these two were
my home at night. Some nights are quieter
than others, apparently.

And so there was this. There was a couple that
were on the street. A couple that were
in a restaurant.

Some of them at the studio also. And so we had these captures. And we were then
wondering, OK, well,

what does it mean to
translate that into a cup? And so here's the challenge,
because how do you transform
a linear scale to texture? And so it's pretty--

the first thing you
might think about is, let's do the version
here on the left. So, basically, a quiet noise
would make a small bump.

And then a louder noise
would make a larger bump. That's pretty obvious. And so that's what we
did on the left one.

So these milliseconds
is actually how long the printer pauses.

And so the longer it
pauses, the more clay is coming out, making a bigger
bump at that moment on the 3D

printer. And so that aligns
with the decibel level. OK.

Fair. So we did that. We did these cups. We looked at them. We're like, OK. But then we, of course, asked,
well, what else can we do?

And so we wondered
what if instead we were trying to showcase human
voice in those recordings.

And so human tone is usually
around 60 to 65 decibels.

And so we made the other score. Or we said, anything
below 60 is going to be really tiny,
tiny little bumps.

And then anything
on these above 65, maybe, could also
be super small.

So anything that is
around voice level, that's going to be the big bumps. And so this is the same
data, those two cups.
They're clearly not the same. And so that's where I think--

that's the first-- this is
one of the first projects I did with data physicalization,
and really working with data,

and the realization
of how much agency the designer or
the artist has in choosing what creating the
boundaries for what meaning

is created of the data
is really powerful. It's a really big
amount of power that you have when
you're choosing,

how do you make
those translations, those transformations.

And so, of course,
we played with it. And we were like, OK,
well, sometimes, perhaps, it becomes really easy to
think about the stories that
are coming out of these cups. When is the morning happening? When is the alarm coming on?

Maybe, this is clear
when this is happening. All of a sudden,
everything is pretty loud.

But sometimes it's
more confusing. So this is one of the
cups that's moving around.

What event do you
think produced that?
A yelling match. Yeah. A big fight, maybe. What else could it be?
Big party. Big party? Yeah.  An ambulance passing through?
Sorry what? An ambulance. Passing. An ambulance passing by. It was pretty loud.

What else? [INAUDIBLE] Yeah. Could it be. I think someone, one time,
told me there was a tiger.
And I was like, what? [LAUGHING] Where do you think I live? But OK.

Actually, this was
the printer's fault. There was a little bit of
clay, a little piece of hay

that was caught in the clay. And so, of course, as the
printer's pushing it down, the clay was
obstructing the nozzle.

And so nothing was coming out. So when you look
at that cup, look at the pieces that are right
before, the bumps are not

the same as the rest. The clay wasn't coming
out, wasn't coming out. And then we pulled it off. And all the clay came
out, because the pressure

had built up. And so this is my
favorite example, because the stories we
think we tell with data

also come from how we
produce the visualizations or the physical
sensations in this case. We can't dissociate the
instrument of producing the data

physicalization from the actual
story or the meaning that's coming through. And so, of course, that's
an extreme example.

Everything else
that you're reading is also now part of why--

part of how this printer works. So this project really
foregrounded tactility,

as opposed to visual approach
to understanding data. And so now, I have these cups.

I drink tea out of them
multiple times a week. And every time I drink
tea, I can't help

but keep on touching
the little bumps and wondering what actually
happened in that moment that

created that bump. And so this tactility
allows for, potentially, this longer engagement with
meaning making in data.

And, of course, the data
stories, how are they produced? How do we know how to
trace back so that we

make sense of the story? Is it the printer? Was it the yelling match or,
a tiger, or whatever it was?

And so these are some of
the two insights there. Also, the other cup
that's going around

that you saw, if you're
comparing both of them, you'll see that we went through
a lot of aesthetic calibration
for this project. So the shorter one is chunkier. It looks like a knit.

And we felt that didn't
allow for as much reading of the data as the
ones that you see here

that are a little bit more fine. And that look a little bit
more like a weave as a way. And so I'm happy to talk a lot
more about this slow process

of fine tuning for
how do you-- and which is like a pretty subjective
approach to what's

the right thing to do here. Questions about the cups, before
I move on to the next project?
You want to see the next one?  All right. The next one is the data epics.

So the data epics
is a collection of 28 stories, which I'll,
maybe, start some here.

And I'll start some over there. The data epics here, instead
of going with something really

material, like the
cups, we, instead, chose to think about fiction
as a way to render data

or to make this creative
data representation. And so, basically,
what this project is is it's really leaning
into the idea

that there is
interpretation happening, when you're translating data. And so if we agree on that, what
happens if you push further?

What happens if you really push
into this interpretative side

of reading through data? And so we worked with
seven fiction writers in the Seattle area and
seven different households,

who lived in their homes with
different devices, IoT devices,

so we had like a Peloton bike,
multiple voice assistants, door

sensors, garage door opener,
camera, thermostat, Sonos,

range of everyday objects
that collect data. And so what we
would do is we would

ask the households to collect
their data for a month. Send it to us. We would anonymize it.

And clean it a little bit. So this is from a
voice assistant. This is from a smart switch.

And so, basically, we
would clean it a little to make it a little
bit more readable. So remove some of the metadata.

So this is from a
voice assistant. You can see some
of the questions.

How much are plane
tickets to England? And then how do you rob a bank?

People ask different
things to voice assistants is what we learned from that. But they knew this was
going to fiction writer.

So I think they were
playing a little. So who knows if they
were really asking, or if they were playing
with the author, which

is part of the interpretation
side of things. So we cleaned it.

When the data was numerical,
we made simple visualizations as a way to help with
the fiction writers just

look at the data. So already, so this is
thermostat over a whole month. So what happened here
on March 6 and 7?

Maybe, they were out of town. I don't know. And then here, this is a bedside
lamp that was in a smart plug.

And so I think it looks
like this person is usually getting around to-- getting
ready for bed around 9.

Turns off the light around 10. But what happens here,
January 3, 3:00 AM?
Something happened.  We can stories out of these.

So, of course,
fiction writers, they have a much broader imagination
than us in a different one.

We give them this. They go on and analyze the data
in whichever way they want.
Write a story. Send it to us. We typeset it. We make the books.

Then we send the books
back to our participants, who now read their data
in the form of a book.

And so it's really hard to
understand this project, if you don't read the story. So I encourage you to read, as
I'm talking, which I rarely say.

But OK. This is one excerpt. So this is elimination. This is the story that is
building on that bedside lamp

visualization that
I just showed. That's how it starts. She is born in darkness.

The absence of light
does not bother her nor does it confuse her. Coming alive with the
imperative of most living things

to move she does. At speeds almost
incomprehensible, she rushes off as
quickly as she can,

determined not to be a laggard. Only knowing that she has a
destination, she must get to.

She does not yet know
what that destination is. Only that she must
get to it and quickly.

So the story is written from the
point of view of the data point. You got that.

And so already, where are we? How is our encounter with
data when we actually

are following data
on its own adventure to go from the light
got turned on to I

need to be in a server
farm in Arizona? And then the story unfolds--

I don't know who has
that book right now-- but the story unfolds. And I might get you the punch. But this one data
point that we're

following in this
story turns out that she was one
of the data points that was really
off in the timing.

And so then we are
following the parallel story of the women who lives in that
house, Page in the story, who

thinks that her
husband is cheating on her, because
this point is off. He's not supposed to be there.

And so she keeps on turning it
on and off, on and off, trying to look at the data point. And this data
point is like, wow.

I'm cast into the sunlight. All this time, it
gets really excited. And then turns out it was
just like a butt dial thing

situation, where there was
no infidelity happening. There was only this
mistake that happened.

And so that's the story. But the stories are
all quite different. There are stories, where the
data is really there wanting

to serve this idea of
servitude is really powerful in a lot of the
stories, which give me pause,

because this is
something we understand very often about data. We create data for our
own benefits as humans.

And so when this comes
back in the story, there's questions from my end of
like, well, what else can it be?

What do data really want? Do they really want to help us? Or can they have something else
they might be interested in?

Some of the stories
from Josh William-- Josh Marie Wilkinson
are very cheeky.

And they're very much
like, you thought you were going to have some
meaning from the story. Think again.

This is like a whole
really surrealist poetry-oriented
story, where it's

really hard to make meaning. And so there's really
something interesting to me about this data pushing
back and saying,

I'm not as malleable
as you think. I can have my own resistance. And then that's really
becoming interesting.

We made a website. It's called dataepics.studio. I encourage you
all to look it up.

That's where all 28 stories are. You can read them. The data that is associated
with the stories are also there.

And so you can understand
what produced what story.

Each author has
about four stories. And you can really get into. If you like a genre,
you can follow it.

When you go on
the home page, you can hover and see what kind
of each story is about. You can read what
data it's coming from.

But, also, some of the stories
are really, really emotional and really about the connection,
very close connection

between people and data. She is my soul. I don't know, if you
can get deeper than that in terms of connection.

But then, sometimes, you get
like, give me a basket of toads. And you're like, OK. This might be more of
a humoristic question.

How do you rob a bank? Got into the story. That's a very fun
one to read too. And then sometimes, it's very
much about the connection

to the body. So Alex Madison,
one of the authors, was really interested
in the conditions
in which data are produced. I was born of her breath. We are both one body and many.

The question of like, where
is the limit or the boundary between the person producing the
data, and then the data itself?

There's all these very
existential questions that also

came through from that project. Will I even outlast you? That could be the
human asking that.
But that could also be the data. So there's a lot of questions. Why do we exist?

To be useful is to be free. That's also a really
weird kind of concept. But really thought provoking.

With each family
or each household,

we worked on four stories. And every story took about three
months to collect the data,

get the story, and give it back. And so we worked with these
people for about a year. And we were really curious.

Well, what's the impact of this? I'm all here saying, and this is
how you change people's minds.

Well, OK, what happened? Two things really
were interesting.

So we met participants
after every story to ask them like,
how's it going?

What did you think
of this story? Could you see your data? Could you see yourself? Does it make you think
about your data differently?

And every time they
would say, I didn't have any expectations
for the story, except I was really expecting
to see myself in it.

And you're like, this
is an expectation. So there was this real
desire to see yourself

in the story, of course. You're giving your
story to somebody who is going to write
a story for you. And there was a disconnect
between how that happened.

And there's this idea
of the data twin, which is common in HCI and also STS.

This idea that data is
an extension of you, a portrait of you.

And I think for
this, there was-- it's more of a distorted
twin or broken mirror twin

that we could see, where
you could get parts of it. Sometimes, you would
see, oh, my god. I did say that.

But I see your question. But there was always
this idea of, well,

I'm open to multiple things. But still, I want to
see glimpses of me. Yes? So maybe I [INAUDIBLE].

Is it in the-- they have different data
sets or are like two stories

from the same data set. Yeah. Each book is a
different data set.

Each household has four stories. Sometimes, if
somebody, for example,

lived with only a
voice assistant, then each story would come from
the same voice assistant,

but at different
times of the year. So you'd get like a January 1,
then like a March or whatever.

And each household worked
with the same author for the whole time. So they could sometimes
recognize the style, not always.

Some households had
multiple devices. And so we would switch
between stories.

And so the first story could
be a voice assist-- well, it could be like a thermostat. The second one could
be the smart bed.

The third one, the
voice assistant. And then the last one,
maybe, the smart home camera. In those cases, we,
usually, try to go

from like more abstract
data to more concrete.

So going from a thermostat,
which, basically, just gives you temperature, to an actual
camera, where you can see what's

going on the street in front. There's different level of
how much you know really from the household.

And then we also asked people,
how's your relationship to data?

How has it changed
over the last year? And they, usually,
say, nothing's changed, except I unplugged the Alexa.

And I don't want
to use it anymore. And you're be like, OK. And that's not related
to the project.
And they were like, not really. I was like, OK. So there is--

I think what this
points to, actually, is this really
subtle change that

happens through this
project, where people are not able to pinpoint directly
what's happening.

And there is a-- I think because it was over
such a long period of time,

and there was both--
the fact that we were asking them to
access their data was a big part of the project so
that they could send it to us.

And that's not a trivial
part of the project. That's actually hard to do
for many of these devices. And so for people
to have to do that,

and then to read the stories,
and us keeping on asking, I think there was a lot
of different probing that

was happening through the
project that had them consider, perhaps, a little differently
how they are engaging with data.

That wasn't the case
for all the households. Some of the households
were like, yeah. I have nothing to hide.

And I still have
nothing to hide. I might maintain how
I live with my data.

But some other
households had some of these shifts happen,
which was interesting

and promising in a
way for this project. Part of this project is
really about building

these new imaginaries. So remember, this image
of the Google search. All the data is just blue
on this black background.

Well, in these stories,
we have so many metaphors around aquatic things, many
metaphors about the body,

many images around
relationships, which is really interesting.

And so we're, actually,
right now working on a dictionary of
data imaginaries that are trying to pull some
of the images here and also

from our conversations
with the participants to start to build
another palette.

It's a different view of what
data can be or feel like. And then this getting closer
point is really about,

our participants in getting
their data from their devices, imagination might be another way
to really get closer to data,

to really start to
think about data, and to have it as part

Soft fading is one
project where we really were trying to turn the
idea of data on its head.

And so instead of
thinking about data as digital, really,
thinking about it as completely analog
and only material.

And so, basically,
what it is is that it's this cylinder with fabric
that was dyed with turmeric,

but not fixed, which means
that it can fade over time. So the fabric in the
beginning, and then

after like five weeks,
if you just leave it like that in the sun. But now, it's on that cylinder.
And it turns. And so it means that every-- it turns one turn a day.

So every day the
same piece of fabric is exposed to the
same kind of light.

So we thought this is what
the fabric would look like, when you take it out.
But then we put it in a home. And we saw this. And we were like, oh, yeah. Shadows and things.

And people move. And you might move it. And so there's all these
other things that happen. And so this really is about
this reminder that the way

data is collected influences
the data, obviously. When the first try we got
this, and we were like,

what is going on? What happened? Turns out we needed
a mechanical engineer

on our team to figure
out how this thing should be turning and not slipping.

So we fixed it. And then we got this. So winter in Seattle,
summer in Seattle.

We have more sun in the summer. It's nicer. But that was the
hypothesis, pretty much.

But what I think is the most
interesting about this project is this idea that there is no
record of every single day.

There is only a
collection, because it just keeps on adding to itself.

It's an archive that
keeps making itself. And you can never go
to the one data point. And that to me, is
such a different way

of thinking about data. And I want to keep
exploring that. The other thing that's
interesting with this project

is, after two months,
maybe, you take it out. If you really like it and
want to pin it on your wall,

it's going to keep on fading. And it'll eventually disappear. And so it really opens up
all these questions about,

do we need to keep the data? Why do we need to
keep all of our data? Can we have this idea of data
disappearing and forgetting?

All these questions
about the right to forget are also entangled in
this project as well.
